name: AnchorWatch

faqs.a: AnchorWatch provides insured, collaborative custody with multisig vaults designed for long‑term bitcoin storage and inheritance.
Yes. Policies are designed to cover bitcoin in AnchorWatch vaults with 1:1 insurance.
Yes. As a regulated provider AnchorWatch requires identity verification.

description:
AnchorWatch is a U.S.-based bitcoin custody and insurance provider trying to bridge traditional insurance with Bitcoin-native custody, delivering peace of mind by offering an elegant, turnkey solution for long‑term bitcoin holders and corporate treasuries seeking secure, insured, and inheritance‑ready custody.

What separates AnchorWatch is their unique integration of protocol-level multisig vaults with time-locked recovery and insurance. Users hold a multi-signature key set alongside AnchorWatch; both are required to sign transactions, and over time additional recovery mechanisms activate to handle key-loss, death, or coercion scenarios.

User reviews and discussions (e.g. from the Build With Bitcoin transcript) emphasize AnchorWatch's layered approach: the combination of vault tech and insurance addresses both technical and human vulnerabilities. The service also supports inheritance planning—time-locked access for heirs without cumbersome "treasure maps". This focus on estate continuity is cited as a major differentiator, especially for non‑technical beneficiaries.

Their future vision includes expanding beyond U.S. customers, offering bespoke large-value enterprise policies, and exploring Bitcoin-denominated insurance.

name: Aqua

faqs.a: Aqua is a non‑custodial mobile wallet supporting Bitcoin, Lightning and Liquid in one interface for easy saving and spending.
No. Aqua is a self‑custodial wallet and does not require KYC to use the app.
Yes. Aqua is open‑source and welcomes community review and contributions.

WW.text: Privacy benefits with confidential transactions on Liquid
Built-in swap between on-chain and Liquid
Relies on Boltz for Lightning swaps

description:
Aqua Wallet, originally launched by Blockstream, later taken over by Jan3, is a mobile app designed for easy saving and spending in Bitcoin. It's a non-custodial, open-source wallet using a 12-word seed phrase for user control, and a unified balance across on-chain Bitcoin, Lightning, and Liquid Network transactions, defaulting to Liquid for low-fee, private payments. It offers sending, receiving, and swapping Bitcoin (on-chain to Liquid or vice versa) but for Lightning payments they rely on Boltz, a third party which can occur higher swap fees. This might affect daily usability for some users.

The app has an intuitive interface - although the design could use some work - and offers seamless swaps between on-chain Bitcoin and Lightning or Liquid.

JAN3's mission is to onboard billions to Bitcoin, with a vision to expand Aqua with debit card integration, credit/loans, and global on/off-ramps. Beginners love its simple setup and versatility, but some find stablecoin options and swap fees confusing.
compat_heading: What this Aqua wallet can or can't do

compat_tiles.title: Pay with Lightning
compat_tiles.benefit: Via Boltz Higher swap fees

compat_tiles.title: Pay on-chain
compat_tiles.benefit: Bitcoin Liquid Built-in swaps

compat_tiles.title: Receive on Lightning
compat_tiles.benefit: Via Boltz Swaps to Liquid or Bitcoin

compat_tiles.title: Receive on-chain
compat_tiles.benefit: Bitcoin Liquid Unified interface

compat_explainers.why: Aqua routes Lightning payments through Boltz swaps, enabling Lightning without native channels.
try: Scan or paste a Lightning invoice
Review the swap fee (typically higher than native Lightning wallets)
Confirm and Aqua swaps from Liquid/on-chain to Lightning
compat_explainers.gotcha: Aqua relies on Boltz for Lightning, which can have higher fees than wallets with native Lightning channels. Best for occasional Lightning use.

compat_explainers.why: Aqua supports both Bitcoin and Liquid networks with seamless swaps between them.
try: Paste a Bitcoin or Liquid address
Aqua auto-detects the network and routes appropriately
Review fee and confirm—Liquid is faster and cheaper
compat_explainers.gotcha: Bitcoin on-chain fees vary with network congestion. Liquid transactions are faster with lower fees but require Liquid-compatible wallets.

compat_explainers.why: Receive Lightning payments that Aqua swaps to your Liquid or Bitcoin balance.
try: Generate a Lightning invoice in Aqua
Share with the payer
Aqua receives via Boltz and settles to Liquid or Bitcoin
compat_explainers.gotcha: Boltz swap fees apply. For frequent Lightning receives, consider a wallet with native Lightning channels like Phoenix or Breez.

compat_explainers.why: Receive both Bitcoin and Liquid in one unified interface with built-in privacy on Liquid.
try: Tap Receive and select Bitcoin or Liquid
Share the address with the sender
Funds appear after confirmations—Liquid is faster (1-2 min)
compat_explainers.gotcha: Liquid transactions offer confidential amounts but require both sender and receiver to use Liquid-compatible wallets.

name: Bisq

faqs.a: Bisq is a decentralized, open‑source desktop app for buying and selling bitcoin directly with other people over Tor using a non‑custodial wallet and no sign‑ups or KYC.
No. Bisq has no accounts or sign‑ups and does not require KYC; trades are peer‑to‑peer with multisig security deposits.
Each trade locks refundable security deposits from both parties in a 2‑of‑2 multisig escrow; account‑age rules and signing raise limits over time to reduce chargeback risk.

WW.text: Liquidity and spreads vary by region
Desktop only; settlement depends on fiat method

fees.intro: Variable; lower if paid in BSQ

description:
Bisq is a decentralized, open‑source desktop app created by Manfred Karrer for buying and selling bitcoin directly with other people. It routes all traffic over Tor, uses a built‑in non‑custodial wallet and has no sign‑ups or KYC. Trades span many national currencies and payment rails, and the project is funded and governed through a community DAO with the BSQ token rather than a company.

What separates Bisq is its security and incentive design for fiat‑to‑BTC P2P. Each trade locks both sides’ refundable security deposits in a 2‑of‑2 multisig escrow. Account‑age and signing rules gradually raise per‑trade limits to reduce chargeback risk, and a small amount of bitcoin is required up front to cover fees and deposits. Trading fees are transparent and lower if paid in BSQ. It’s desktop‑first by design; the mobile app is for notifications.

User feedback highlights Bisq’s strengths in privacy, censorship resistance and self‑custody, along with clear, step‑by‑step trade flows and a multi‑stage dispute process if things go wrong.

The trade‑offs are thinner liquidity depending on region, wider spreads than convenience brokers, the need to already have a little bitcoin, and settlement times tied to the chosen fiat method and counterparties’ availability. Some users note that disputes can take time, and that desktop performance varies by setup.

Bisq’s target audience is privacy‑minded bitcoiners and anyone who needs a resilient, non‑custodial fiat ramp. The roadmap is to keep the marketplace permissionless while improving UX and resilience: Bisq 2 introduces a simpler “Bisq Easy” path alongside the familiar multisig protocol, support for multiple privacy networks, and optional use of Liquid for faster, lower‑fee settlement.

name: Bitkey

faqs.a: Bitkey is a 2‑of‑3 multisig wallet combining a mobile app, hardware device, and cloud backup to make self‑custody simple for beginners.

faqs.q: Do I need to memorize a seed phrase?
faqs.a: No. Bitkey replaces traditional seed phrases with device pairing and an encrypted cloud backup for recovery.

faqs.q: Can I connect Bitkey to my own node?
faqs.a: Yes. Bitkey supports connecting to your own Bitcoin node for improved privacy and verification.

custody_control: Shared custody: you hold two out of three keys
description:
Bitkey is a mobile and hardware wallet developed by Block and designed for people new to Bitcoin who want simple, secure self-custody. The system combines a phone app with a wireless hardware device and an encrypted cloud backup, using a 2-of-3 multisig model to keep users in control of their funds. This structure allows users to recover access even if they lose their phone or the device, adding safety without relying on seed phrases.

The hardware, a sleek hexagonal device with a fingerprint sensor and NFC for phone pairing, eliminates the need for complex seed phrases, making it user-friendly. Sending Bitcoin requires both your phone and the Bitkey device, while smaller transactions can be approved using just your phone and Bitkey's server key if you've set spending limits. This balance appeals to people who want more security than just a phone wallet but don't want the complexity of most hardware wallets.

Users can set daily spending limits for app-only transactions, adding flexibility. The setup is quick, often taking just 5 minutes, and the app's clean interface is intuitive. The app allows Bitcoin purchases, shows balance in both sats and fiat, and offers recovery through trusted contacts in case of loss. It also lacks a screen, meaning you can't visually verify addresses on the hardware itself.

Bitkey's mission is to bring secure Bitcoin ownership to a global audience, especially those new to Bitcoin, by removing friction and avoiding the pitfalls of traditional backups. Their future vision includes broader international support, expanded wallet functionality, and continued emphasis on open-source development and user control. For beginners, Bitkey offers a straightforward, secure way to own Bitcoin with a polished user experience, though advanced users may want more flexibility.

name: Bitonic

faqs.a: Bitonic is the Netherlands' oldest Bitcoin‑only broker, offering fast iDEAL and SEPA buys with automatic delivery to your wallet.
Yes. Auto Invest allows recurring buys; fees may apply beyond the free monthly tier.
Bitonic is custodial for purchases, but encourages self‑custody and supports automatic withdrawals to your own wallet.

WW.text: Bitcoin will automatically be sent to your wallet

EU.text: Bitcoin will automatically be sent to your wallet

dca: Yes: but free only on the first €250 with every purchase
profile: Robert de Waard, Jouke Hofman & Niels van Groningen
description:
Bitonic is the oldest and largest Bitcoin-only broker in the Netherlands, founded in 2012, with a reputation for reliability and simplicity. They offer fast, automatic Bitcoin delivery via iDEAL, SEPA, and Bancontact, and their fully automated system ensures quick transfers.

It stands out with its direct purchase model, selling Bitcoin from its own stock for instant delivery and transparent pricing, avoiding third-party intermediaries. Bitonic offers buying, selling, and saving Bitcoin via iDEAL, SEPA, or Bancontact and provide an Auto Invest savings feature, allowing users to easily set up recurring Bitcoin purchases, (though only up to €250 | 271,023 sats) and a business solution for Bitcoin payments.

Its app, rated 4.5 stars on iOS, is praised for its clean, no-nonsense design, though some users report slow verification. The platform uses multi-signature cold storage for security and encourages self-custody with personal wallets.

Their vision focuses on making Bitcoin accessible and easy for Dutch and European users, backed by education through Bitonic Academy and news via Bitcoin.nl. Overall, Bitonic is ideal for beginners who want a reliable, no-altcoin platform in Europe, with fast transactions, clear pricing and a strong local support.

name: Breez

faqs.a: Breez is a non‑custodial Lightning wallet with PoS mode and a podcast player for streaming sats to creators.
Yes. Breez uses a cloud backup to restore your wallet and Lightning channels, which some users prefer for convenience.
Yes. Breez is open‑source and actively developed with the community.

WW.text: Not ideal for micro payments (<100 sats)

custody_control: Non-custodial: you hold your own keys
description:
Breez (Misty Breez) focuses on making Lightning Network payments fast and easy. It stands out with its non-custodial mobile app, letting users control their Bitcoin, and a unique Point-of-Sale mode for merchants to accept instant payments. It offers sending, receiving, and storing Bitcoin via Lightning, plus a podcast player to support creators with Bitcoin tips.

The app has a simple interface and no-setup payments, though some users report issues with cloud backups and wallet restoration.

Breez's mission is to drive Bitcoin adoption for everyday use, with a vision to expand Lightning payments across apps using its Breez SDK, a free developer tool. The app currently suits everyday payments rather than very small transactions. Beginners love its ease and merchant tools, but some find technical issues frustrating.
compat_heading: What this Breez wallet can or can't do

compat_tiles.title: Pay with Lightning
compat_tiles.benefit: Invoices Pay links Lightning Address

compat_tiles.title: Pay on-chain
compat_tiles.benefit: Via swap to on-chain

compat_tiles.title: Receive on Lightning
compat_tiles.benefit: Invoices Pay links Auto-managed

compat_tiles.title: Receive on-chain
compat_tiles.benefit: Swaps to Lightning

compat_explainers.why: Breez is a native Lightning wallet with full support for modern Lightning features.
try: Scan or paste any Lightning invoice, LNURL, or Lightning Address
Review the routing fee (typically very low)
Confirm and payment settles instantly
compat_explainers.gotcha: Not ideal for very small payments under 100 sats due to minimum channel reserves.

compat_explainers.why: You can send to Bitcoin addresses via reverse submarine swaps.
try: Paste a Bitcoin address in the Send field
Breez routes via reverse submarine swap to on-chain
Review swap fee and confirm
compat_explainers.gotcha: Reverse swaps include service fees plus on-chain mining fees. Check total cost before confirming.

compat_explainers.why: Breez handles Lightning channel liquidity automatically in the background.
try: Tap Receive to generate a Lightning invoice
Share the QR or invoice with the payer
Breez manages channel capacity behind the scenes
compat_explainers.gotcha: First receive or liquidity adjustments may take time. Keep the app open while receiving large amounts.

compat_explainers.why: Receive Bitcoin from exchanges or on-chain wallets; Breez swaps it to Lightning.
try: Tap Receive and select Bitcoin address option
Share the address with the sender
After confirmations, Breez swaps the funds to your Lightning balance
compat_explainers.gotcha: Submarine swaps to Lightning include service fees. Consider the cost for small on-chain receives.

name: BTC Pay

faqs.a: BTCPay Server is a free, open‑source, self‑hosted Bitcoin and Lightning payment processor that sends payments directly to your wallet.
No platform fees are charged by BTCPay; you only pay standard Bitcoin/Lightning network fees and your hosting costs.
No. It's non‑custodial—private keys stay under your control.

faqs.q: Is BTCPay difficult to set up?
faqs.a: Setup can be technical, but guides and one‑click deployments make it manageable for motivated beginners.
BTCPay integrates with WooCommerce, Shopify (via bridge), Magento, and many more ecommerce platforms.

compatibility: Big Commerce, Drupal, Ecwid, GiveWP, Grandnode, Invoice Ninja, Magento, Nopcommerce, Odoo, OpenCart, PhocaCart, PrestaShop, Pretix, Shopify V2, Shopware, Ghost, Smartstore, VirtueMart, Wix, WooCommerce, Xenforo, Zapier, Custom Integration
description:
BTC Pay Server, developed by a community-driven open-source project, is a self-hosted Bitcoin payment processor designed to empower merchants and individuals to accept Bitcoin payments securely and privately without intermediaries. All payments go directly to the user's own wallet—private keys stay under user control, greatly enhancing privacy and censorship resistance.

Unlike other payment solutions, users can create online stores, point‑of‑sale systems, tipping buttons, crowdfunding campaigns, or invoice links—all within a single interface. It avoids KYC, middleman fees, and personal data collection, appealing to anyone seeking financial sovereignty with seamless integration to hardware wallets or custodial services.

Users highlight its open‑source, self‑hosted nature and flexibility, commenting on how easy it is to connect a cloud‑hosted or home server, link a Bitcoin wallet, and enable Lightning payments—empowering them to accept Bitcoin anywhere, anytime, though some note the initial setup complexity for beginners.

BTCPay Server's mission is to democratize Bitcoin payments—removing fees, intermediaries, and technical barriers. Their vision for the future includes releasing a mobile app to enable non‑custodial Lightning payments for merchants, refining multisig and fee‑acceleration tools, and expanding e‑commerce integrations.

name: Bull Bitcoin

faqs.a: Bull Bitcoin is a non‑custodial Bitcoin service that sends purchases directly to your own wallet and supports bill payments in Canada.

faqs.q: Is KYC required at Bull Bitcoin?
faqs.a: For buying and selling, identity verification applies by jurisdiction; the platform focuses on privacy and self‑custody.
Canada is the primary market, with expanding international access and features available in select regions.

description:
Bull Bitcoin is a Canadian Bitcoin exchange that stands out by being entirely non-custodial, meaning users must provide their own wallet and take full ownership of their Bitcoin. It allows users to buy Bitcoin directly to their own wallets, sell Bitcoin instantly without waiting for confirmations, and even pay bills, rent, and credit cards in Canada by converting Bitcoin to fiat without relying on traditional banks. This approach positions Bitcoin as a tool for everyday exchange, not just long-term saving.

The platform (the mobile app is in beta) is self-funded, Bitcoin-only, and deeply ideological, rejecting external investors. Its team identifies as cypherpunks, building open-source tools and promoting financial sovereignty. Bull Bitcoin's mission is to create sovereign individuals through uncompromising adherence to Bitcoin principles, making it attractive to users who want to align their actions with their values.

Beginners find the platform easy to use, with a clean interface and responsive support, while advanced users appreciate its strong privacy stance and no-compromise philosophy. It's ideal for Canadians and expanding internationally for those who want full control over their Bitcoin without depending on custodians or legacy finance systems.

name: Fold

faqs.a: Fold is a Bitcoin rewards app with a prepaid debit card and gift cards that earn sats on everyday spending.
Fold holds balances in your account until you withdraw; rewards can be sent to your own wallet.
Most card features are U.S.‑only; gift cards and rewards access may vary by region.

supported_network: Visa Debit Card, Credit Card, Giftcards

WW.text: Seamless integration of Bitcoin into traditional finance
High fees possible on some services

US.text: 2% unlimited Bitcoin rewards on credit card

description:
Fold aims to make Bitcoin accessible by integrating it into daily financial activities. It offers a Visa prepaid debit card, gift card purchases, and bill payments, all rewarding users with Bitcoin (sats). Users can also buy Bitcoin with low or no fees, depending on their plan, and deposit Bitcoin into their Fold account for insured custody.

What sets Fold apart is how it combines traditional finance functions like bill pay and debit card usage with Bitcoin rewards in one simple interface. Users don't need to juggle multiple apps or wallets. Rewards can be earned on nearly every transaction, from daily spending to mortgage payments, with bonus sats for gift card purchases. Fold also allows external Bitcoin deposits and provides low-fee conversions from paycheck to BTC, making it easy to live on a Bitcoin standard while minimizing taxable events.

Users praise the ease of use, the ability to stack Bitcoin passively, and the clear design of the app. Some power users run most of their household finances through Fold, using the gift card section for groceries and shopping, and setting up recurring buys with leftover balances at the end of each month. The ability to earn rewards even on ACH bill pay is seen as a unique benefit.

Fold's vision is to be the ultimate platform for living on a Bitcoin standard, making it easy to earn, spend, and save Bitcoin while navigating a fiat world, giving users control and flexibility without the complexity of traditional exchanges or wallets.
compat_heading: What this Fold wallet can or can't do

compat_tiles.title: Pay with Lightning
compat_tiles.benefit: Via Visa card Converts to fiat

compat_tiles.title: Pay on-chain
compat_tiles.benefit: Via Visa card Can withdraw on-chain

compat_tiles.title: Receive on Lightning
compat_tiles.benefit: Lightning deposits Custodial account

compat_tiles.title: Receive on-chain
compat_tiles.benefit: Bitcoin deposits Custodial account

compat_explainers.why: Fold lets you spend Bitcoin anywhere Visa is accepted—your balance converts to fiat at checkout.
try: Load your Fold account with Bitcoin or Lightning
Use your Fold Visa debit card anywhere
Earn Bitcoin rewards on purchases (varies by plan)
compat_explainers.gotcha: You're not paying Lightning directly to merchants—Fold converts your balance to USD at payment time. This creates taxable events.

compat_explainers.why: Use your Bitcoin balance for everyday spending via the Fold Visa card, or withdraw on-chain.
try: Tap Send and enter a Bitcoin address to withdraw on-chain
Or use your Fold Visa card anywhere—balance converts to fiat
Review fees before confirming withdrawals
compat_explainers.gotcha: Card payments trigger fiat conversion (taxable event). On-chain withdrawals incur mining fees. Check fee structure before large withdrawals.

compat_explainers.why: Deposit Bitcoin via Lightning to your Fold account for spending or holding.
try: Tap Receive and generate a Lightning invoice
Send from another wallet to your Fold Lightning address
Funds appear in your custodial Fold account
compat_explainers.gotcha: Fold is custodial—they hold your Bitcoin until you withdraw. Consider moving large amounts to self-custody.

compat_explainers.why: Deposit Bitcoin from exchanges or other wallets directly to your Fold account.
try: Tap Receive and get your Bitcoin deposit address
Send from exchange or another wallet
Funds appear after confirmations in your Fold balance
compat_explainers.gotcha: Fold holds your Bitcoin custodially. Withdrawals to your own wallet are possible but incur on-chain fees.

name: Hodlhodl

faqs.a: Hodl Hodl is a peer‑to‑peer Bitcoin marketplace using multisig escrow so you trade directly with others without custodial risk.
No. You can trade without KYC, though building reputation improves pricing and limits.
Many methods are supported—bank transfer, Revolut, cash in person and more—depending on the seller and country.

WW.text: Required to build reputation on closed platform

description:
Hodl Hodl is a peer-to-peer (p2p) Bitcoin trading and lending platform based in London that stands out by being fully non-custodial and privacy-focused. Instead of holding funds, it uses multisig escrow contracts, so users retain control of their Bitcoin until both parties agree to release it, shifting trust from the exchange to individual traders, as trades happen directly between user's Bitcoin wallets rather than a centralized entity.

What separates Hodl Hodl from custodial platforms is its ability to let people trade without KYC (Know Your Customer) or central control, supporting over 100 currencies and various payment methods including cash, bank transfers, even PayPal. You do pay a higher premium on Bitcoin set by the seller, especially when you're a beginner and have to build a reputation on the platform.

The web-based interface is beginner-friendly, praised by users for easy signup without mandatory ID checks, though users note clunky navigation and scam risks from unresponsive traders. To unlock significant transaction amounts, users must build trust through reviews and completed trades, as higher limits depend on a strong reputation score.

Hodl Hodl's vision is to foster a decentralized Bitcoin economy, ideal for beginners who want self-custody and anonymity, but users should be careful, stay informed, and follow best practices during trades.

name: Lightspark

faqs.a: Lightspark provides enterprise Lightning infrastructure and APIs to send and receive global payments with low latency and cost.
Lightspark supports self‑custodial wallets via Spark and also offers managed nodes for enterprises that need it.
Digital banks, wallets, exchanges and fintechs needing scalable Bitcoin/Lightning payments and fiat interoperability.

WW.text: Instant, low-cost global payments and fiat interoperability
Enterprise-focused, may require custom setup for small users
Managed nodes introduce some custodial elements

compatibility: SDKs and APIs for wallets, exchanges, digital banks; Integrates with fiat rails (e.g., RTP) and Lightning Network
custody_control: Flexible: Supports self-custodial wallets via Spark; Managed nodes for enterprises
description:
Lightspark is a payments infrastructure company founded by David Marcus (formerly of PayPal, Meta, and Diem) in 2022. They aim to build what they call the "Money Grid," a global, open payment network using Bitcoin as a neutral settlement layer and leveraging Lightning for high-speed transfers.

Their target audience includes enterprises—digital banks, fintechs, wallets, exchanges—that need to move money across currencies and jurisdictions instantly and cheaply, as well as developers building Bitcoin-native payment applications or self-custodial wallets that need scalable infrastructure.

What sets Lightspark apart is their end-to-end product integration, combining seamless liquidity management, intelligent routing, compliance-ready infrastructure, and human-friendly Universal Money Address (UMA) tech. This abstraction lets banks, wallets, exchanges, and businesses effortlessly send and receive fiat or crypto globally without having to manage Lightning channels, cross-border FX, or complex on-chain details. These tools have already seen traction with big regulated partners and typically involves KYC via the partner.

Looking forward, Lightspark's vision is to scale the Money Grid globally—connecting all real-time payment systems and making Bitcoin native rails for everything from everyday consumer transfers to B2B fiat-fiat flows. Spark aims to resolve key Lightning limitations like self-custody economic scalability and lacks native token support. By building Spark open-source and fully backward compatible with Lightning, they hope to decentralize stablecoin issuance on Bitcoin and finally realize high-velocity, global Bitcoin-based payment settlement.

name: Muun

faqs.a: Muun is a non‑custodial Bitcoin and Lightning wallet that chooses the best network automatically for each payment.
Muun uses an email and encrypted recovery code instead of a traditional 12‑word seed phrase.
Yes. Muun is open‑source and widely reviewed by the community.
Muun requires two signatures to spend: one from your phone and one from Muun's server, ensuring both security and convenience for daily transactions.

faqs.q: How can I restore Muun after losing my phone?
faqs.a: Use your Emergency Kit PDF combined with your Recovery Code to restore full access; both pieces are required.

recovery_method: Emergency kit with email and recovery code
description:
Muun is a non-custodial Bitcoin and Lightning wallet focused on giving users full control with minimal complexity. It separates itself from other wallets through its unique security and backup model: users recover access using an email, password, and encrypted recovery code—removing the need to manage a traditional 12-word seed phrase. This makes onboarding easier for beginners without compromising self-custody.

Muun's key differentiator is how it handles both Lightning and on-chain Bitcoin in one seamless balance. Users don't have to manage channels or worry about liquidity—Muun automates that behind the scenes. You can send or receive Bitcoin however you want, and the wallet figures out whether to use Lightning or regular Bitcoin based on speed, cost, and availability. This hybrid approach appeals to users who want convenience but still own their funds.

Users praise Muun for its simple design, clear recovery process, and solid privacy. It's especially recommended for first-time users who want a secure but low-friction experience. However, some note that Muun doesn't support Lightning addresses and that Lightning transactions may route via on-chain swaps. This means unpredictable fees, especially when onchain activity rises.

Muun's mission is to provide a simple, secure way to use Bitcoin daily without needing technical knowledge. It prioritizes non-custodial access, user control, and cross-platform consistency, helping new users enter Bitcoin while retaining ownership from day one.

tl_dr.best_for: Beginners who want automatic network selection and no manual channel management.
tl_dr.consider_if: You want both Lightning and on-chain in one seamless balance without technical complexity.
tl_dr.not_ideal_when: You need Lightning addresses or want predictable low fees during high on-chain activity.

steps.title: 1. Install and create Emergency Kit
actions: Install Muun from App Store or Google Play
Create your account with email and password
Generate and save your Emergency Kit PDF (can store in cloud—it's encrypted)
Write down your Recovery Code on paper and keep it safe
steps.gotcha: You need BOTH the Emergency Kit AND Recovery Code to restore. Neither alone is enough to access your funds.

steps.title: 2. Receive your first Bitcoin
actions: Tap Receive and choose Lightning or Bitcoin address
Muun automatically handles the network selection
Share the QR code or address with your payer
Funds appear instantly for Lightning, or after confirmations for on-chain
steps.gotcha: Lightning payments may use submarine swaps which can have higher fees than native Lightning wallets during busy periods.

steps.title: 3. Make a payment
actions: Tap Send and scan or paste an invoice or address
Muun automatically chooses Lightning or on-chain based on the payment
Review the amount and fee estimate, then confirm
Payment completes instantly for Lightning or after confirmations for on-chain
steps.gotcha: Fees can be unpredictable. Muun may use on-chain transactions for Lightning payments when network conditions require it.

fees_scenarios.title: Send Lightning
fees_scenarios.cost_today: Network routing fees (typically <10 sats for small amounts)
fees_scenarios.what_happens: Muun routes your Lightning payment automatically.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Lightning fees are already minimal and scale with payment size.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: Lightning payments through Muun are fast and cheap when routing works cleanly. The wallet handles all the complexity—you just see the total fee before confirming.

fees_scenarios.title: Receive Lightning (submarine swap)
fees_scenarios.cost_today: On-chain mining fee + swap service fee (varies $2-$50+)
fees_scenarios.what_happens: Muun uses an on-chain transaction to enable your Lightning receive—you pay the fee, not the sender.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Check mempool.space before requesting large Lightning payments; avoid receiving when on-chain fees are high.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: When you receive Lightning but Muun needs to establish payment capacity, it uses a submarine swap—an on-chain transaction that enables the Lightning payment. Unlike most Lightning wallets, YOU (the receiver) pay this fee. This is the main cost tradeoff of Muun's automatic channel management.

fees_scenarios.title: Send Bitcoin on-chain
fees_scenarios.what_happens: Your payment is broadcast to the Bitcoin network and confirmed in blocks.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Send during weekends or low-activity periods; consolidate outputs when fees are cheap.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: Muun's fee estimator uses real-time mempool data to suggest optimal fees. You won't overpay when the network is quiet, but you'll pay market rate during busy periods.

fees_faq.q: Why are Muun's fees sometimes higher than other Lightning wallets?
fees_faq.a: Muun uses submarine swaps to provide seamless Lightning payments without manual channel management. This convenience comes with potentially higher fees when on-chain activity is high.

fees_faq.q: How does Muun's fee estimator work?
fees_faq.a: Muun uses a mempool-based estimator that looks at current network conditions, not past blocks. This helps you pay efficient fees—not overpaying when the network is quiet, nor underestimating when it's busy.

fees_faq.q: Can I control whether Muun uses Lightning or on-chain?
fees_faq.a: Muun automatically chooses the best method based on the payment type and network conditions. You'll see the fee estimate before confirming.

key_terms.definition: An on-chain Bitcoin transaction that enables Lightning payments when direct channel routing isn't possible. In Muun, YOU pay for this when receiving.
Fee paid to Bitcoin miners to include your transaction in a block. Varies with network demand; check mempool.space for current rates.

data_flows: Muun uses a 2-of-2 multisig model: one key on your phone, one on Muun's server. Muun co-signs your transactions for daily use.
For Lightning payments, Muun servers can see transaction amounts and timing needed for routing.
On-chain transactions are public by design; address reuse can link your activity.
Your Emergency Kit contains both keys encrypted—neither Muun nor attackers can access funds without your Recovery Code.
privacy.data_flows_do: Use Muun's automatic network selection to benefit from both Lightning and on-chain privacy features.
privacy.data_flows_dont: Assume complete privacy—Muun's cooperative model means some metadata is visible to Muun servers.
recovery: Your Emergency Kit (PDF) and Recovery Code (paper) together give you full self-custody. Neither piece alone can access funds.
Standard restore: install Muun → enter email/password → wallet syncs automatically. For full recovery use your Emergency Kit + Recovery Code.
If Muun servers go offline: decrypt your Emergency Kit with your Recovery Code to access both private keys independently.
Your keys are stored in two places: one on your phone (hot) and one on Muun's server (hot), but both are encrypted in your Emergency Kit (cold).
privacy.recovery_do: Store your Emergency Kit in multiple secure locations (it's encrypted). Keep your Recovery Code on paper, never digital.
privacy.recovery_dont: Lose both the Emergency Kit and Recovery Code—you need them together for full self-custody.
region: Muun is available worldwide through official app stores.
Download only from the official publisher on Apple App Store or Google Play.
Verify the developer name (Muun) before installing.

micro_faqs.a: No. While Muun holds one key for daily transactions, they never have both keys decrypted simultaneously. Your Emergency Kit ensures full self-custody.

micro_faqs.q: What if I lose my phone?
micro_faqs.a: Install Muun on a new phone, log in with email/password. For full recovery without Muun, use your Emergency Kit + Recovery Code.
Use your Emergency Kit + Recovery Code to access both private keys and sweep your funds independently.

glossary.def: Requires two signatures to spend funds—one from you, one from Muun—ensuring security and convenience.
PDF with your encrypted keys and output descriptors for independent recovery.
Random characters that decrypt your Emergency Kit; has more entropy than a 12-word mnemonic.

compat_heading: What this Muun wallet can or can't do

compat_tiles.title: Pay with Lightning
compat_tiles.benefit: Invoices Pay links Lightning Address

compat_tiles.title: Pay on-chain
compat_tiles.benefit: Native on-chain Auto-selects network

compat_tiles.title: Receive on Lightning
compat_tiles.benefit: Uses swaps You pay swap fee

compat_tiles.title: Receive on-chain
compat_tiles.benefit: Native Unified balance

compat_explainers.why: Muun automatically routes Lightning payments via submarine swaps when needed.
try: Scan or paste any BOLT11 invoice or LNURL
Review fee estimate—can be higher than native Lightning wallets
Confirm and payment completes instantly
compat_explainers.gotcha: Lightning Address (user@domain.com) is not yet supported. Muun may use on-chain swaps for Lightning sends, increasing fees during busy periods.

compat_explainers.why: Muun lets you send to any Bitcoin address with automatic network selection.
try: Paste a Bitcoin address in the Send field
Muun auto-selects on-chain routing
Review mining fee and confirm
compat_explainers.gotcha: On-chain fees vary with network congestion. Check mempool.space before sending large amounts.

compat_explainers.why: Muun uses submarine swaps to receive Lightning payments without managing channels.
try: Tap Receive and generate a Lightning invoice
Share with the payer
Muun handles the swap automatically—YOU pay the on-chain fee, not the sender
compat_explainers.gotcha: Unlike most Lightning wallets, YOU (the receiver) pay the submarine swap fee (on-chain mining fee + service fee). This can be $2–$50+ when the network is busy.

compat_explainers.why: Receive from exchanges and other wallets directly to your unified balance.
try: Tap Receive → Bitcoin address
Share the address with the sender
Funds appear after confirmations in your unified balance
compat_explainers.gotcha: Muun shows one balance for both Lightning and on-chain—convenient but different from channel-based wallets.

migration.title: Restore Muun on a new phone
migration.choose: When you get a new device and want to keep using Muun.
steps: Install Muun on the new phone from the official app store.
Log in with your email and password—your wallet syncs automatically.
Verify your balance and transaction history appear correctly.
migration.tips: Keep your Emergency Kit and Recovery Code safe—they're your ultimate backup if email access fails.
migration.gotcha: If you lose email access, you'll need your Emergency Kit + Recovery Code for full recovery.

migration.title: Another wallet → to Muun
migration.choose: When you want to start using Muun but have funds elsewhere.
steps: Install Muun and complete the setup (Emergency Kit + Recovery Code).
In Muun, tap Receive and choose Lightning or Bitcoin depending on your source wallet.
Send from your old wallet to Muun. Start with a small test amount first.
migration.tips: Always test with a small amount first. Muun handles both Lightning and on-chain automatically—choose what works best for your source wallet.
migration.gotcha: Muun may use submarine swaps for Lightning receives, which can incur on-chain fees if network is busy.

migration.title: Muun → to cold storage
migration.choose: When you want to move Bitcoin to long-term storage.
steps: Get a receiving address from your cold storage wallet.
In Muun, tap Send and paste the cold storage address.
Review the fee and confirm—wait for blockchain confirmations.
migration.tips: Check current mining fees before sending. Consider waiting for weekends when fees are typically lower.
migration.gotcha: On-chain confirmations can take 10 minutes to several hours depending on network activity and fee paid.

migration.title: Muun → to another wallet
migration.choose: When you want to try a different wallet and move your balance.
steps: Install and set up your new wallet completely.
Test with a small payment (~10,000 sats) from Muun to the new wallet.
Once verified, send the remaining balance from Muun to your new wallet.
migration.tips: Test first with a small amount. Keep both wallets until you confirm the full transfer succeeded.
migration.gotcha: Different wallets have different recovery models—make sure you understand your new wallet's backup system before moving funds.

name: myNode
type_of_platform: Home server as software and / or hardware

faqs.a: myNode is a turnkey Bitcoin and Lightning node platform with a polished web UI and many integrated apps.
Core software is free; premium features and supported hardware are available for a fee.
Raspberry Pi, DIY x86 hardware, and prebuilt myNode devices.

price:
Free software
$79 for premium software
$399 Model One hardware device
$599 Model Two hardware device
description:
MyNode is a turnkey Bitcoin and Lightning node platform that combines open‑source software with a polished, full‑featured web interface, making it accessible to both novices and advanced users.

What sets MyNode apart is its integration of a wide array of Bitcoin tools all in one place—your own full node, Lightning (via LND), Electrum server, block explorers, wallet pairing tools and more—coordinated through an intuitive UI.

The target audience ranges from beginners who can get started with simple, plug‑and‑play hardware builds or prebuilt units, to seasoned users. The Premium+ hardware options (Model One/Two) bundle top‑spec hardware with built‑in support and warranty, while DIYers can start with the free software and chosen hardware.

Looking ahead, MyNode continues to expand its ecosystem with new beta apps and features plus consistent rapid updates and community‑driven development. Their vision is clear: empower individuals to run a sovereign, private, and all‑in‑one Bitcoin infrastructure at home, easily and robustly, with ongoing innovation and support.

name: OpenNode

faqs.a: OpenNode is a Bitcoin payment processor for businesses with hosted checkouts, plugins and APIs.
Funds are custodial until withdrawal or automatic settlement to your bank or wallet.
Fees are typically around 1% depending on product and volume; see pricing for details.

WW.text: Fees can add up for high-volume businesses

description:
OpenNode is a Bitcoin-first payment processor that empowers businesses to accept and send Bitcoin—either on-chain or via Lightning—using simple plugins, hosted checkouts, or its developer-friendly API. Organisations that want a turnkey, compliant solution—especially mid-sized to large enterprises—can onboard easily with KYC and achieve global scale without building complex node infrastructure.

It offers instant, low-cost microtransactions with a focus on liquidity management, channel operations, and protocol support. For merchants, this means accessing Bitcoin payments both instantly and economically, alongside automatic settlement options in fiat or BTC. By abstracting away technical complexities like node handling, liquidity, and channel balance, OpenNode allows businesses to plug-and-play and scale efficiently.

It holds US regulatory licenses, manages KYC requirements, and maintains automated fiat conversions and payouts. This makes it ideal for businesses—especially blue-chip and enterprise-level—that require solid legal and financial backstops.

Their long-term vision is to see global businesses and platforms integrate Bitcoin payments as seamlessly as credit cards—secure, censorship-resistant, and frictionless—while pushing forward broader adoption of Bitcoin as a unit of exchange across borders and cultures.

name: Peach

faqs.a: Peach is a mobile peer‑to‑peer marketplace to buy and sell Bitcoin with non‑custodial multisig escrow.
No for smaller trades; limits and verification depend on region and payment method.

faqs.q: Which payment methods does Peach support?
faqs.a: Many options including bank transfer, cash in person and regional fintech apps depending on your counterpart.

WW.text: Required to build reputation on closed platform

description:
Peach Bitcoin is a mobile-only peer-to-peer platform for buying and selling Bitcoin. It stands out with its non-custodial model, using multi-signature escrow to secure trades without holding user funds, shifting trust to individual traders, and offering KYC-free (Know Your Customer) transactions up to 1,000 CHF daily, emphasizing privacy.

Users must build trust through reviews and completed trades to unlock higher transaction limits. It supports over 100 payment methods, including cash and gift cards, with a 2% fee for buyers and free selling.

Peach's mission is to make peer-to-peer Bitcoin trading the standard, promoting financial freedom, with plans to enhance Lightning Network support and expand globally, especially in Latin America and Africa. The vision is to offer a private, on‑the‑go way to trade Bitcoin without heavy identity requirements, making it attractive to beginners who want control and privacy without overcomplicating the process. Beginners love its privacy and ease, but some find the mobile-only platform limiting.

name: Phoenix

faqs.q: What fees apply when I pay over Lightning?
faqs.a: Phoenix charges 0.4% plus 4 sat for every Lightning payment you send.

faqs.q: What happens if I lack inbound liquidity when receiving?
faqs.a: Phoenix may open or splice a channel and charge 1% of the amount plus the mining fee when incoming liquidity is insufficient.

faqs.q: How private are Phoenix payments today?
faqs.a: ACINQ sees the destination and amount of your payments for now, although privacy upgrades are planned.

faqs.q: How do on-chain deposits work in Phoenix?
faqs.a: Phoenix gives you a Bitcoin address; after three confirmations the app swaps the funds to Lightning if fees are below your limit.

faqs.q: How can I restore Phoenix after losing my phone?
faqs.a: Install Phoenix, choose Restore my wallet, enter the 12-word seed, and let channels resync; Android history will not migrate.

supported_network: Lightning only, but you can receive and send on-chain using swaps

WW.text: Option to connect your own node
High on-chain fees for channel creation

description:
Phoenix is designed to provide a simple, self-custodial experience for fast, low-cost Lightning transactions directly on mobile devices, emphasizing ease of use for beginners.

Phoenix runs a native Lightning node on the user's device, connecting to ACINQ's node for automated channel management, eliminating the need for swaps and reducing fees for direct Lightning payments. Additionally, Phoenix allows connections to a user's own Bitcoin node for enhanced privacy.

For beginners, Phoenix's intuitive UI, low-cost Lightning transactions, and self-custodial design make it ideal for those starting with Bitcoin, though channel size limitations may require occasional fee adjustments for frequent receivers. Compared to Breez's merchant-centric features or Aqua's Liquid-focused versatility, Phoenix excels in delivering a straightforward, cost-effective Lightning experience with robust privacy options.

tl_dr.best_for: Mobile-first Lightning payments with self-custody and automated channel care.
tl_dr.consider_if: You expect to receive euro Lightning tips without running your own node.
tl_dr.not_ideal_when: You need desktop access or stronger payment privacy.

steps.title: 1. Install and secure your wallet
actions: Install Phoenix from App Store or Google Play
Write down your 12-word seed on paper and store it away from your device
Enable biometric lock on your phone
steps.gotcha: Never upload the seed to email, chat apps, or cloud drives.

steps.title: 2. Receive your first sats
actions: Tap Receive to generate a Lightning invoice
Share the QR code with your payer
Keep the app awake until payment settles
steps.gotcha: First payment may open a channel and charge ~1,000 sat plus current mining fees if the network is busy.

steps.title: 3. Make a payment
actions: Tap Send and scan or paste a Lightning invoice
Review the amount and memo, then confirm
Wait for the success banner (Phoenix retries automatically if needed)
steps.gotcha: For large invoices, adjust the maximum acceptable fee in Settings → Channel management before sending.

fees_scenarios.title: Pay someone
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Avoid lots of tiny payments when the network is busy.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: Every outgoing Lightning payment includes this fee. The 4 sat is Phoenix's service charge, and the 0.4% covers routing through the Lightning network.

fees_scenarios.title: First time you receive
fees_scenarios.cost_today: ≈1,000 sat channel creation + current mining fee
fees_scenarios.what_happens: Phoenix opens a Lightning channel so you can receive payments.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Wait for low on-chain fees (check mempool.space); receive when network is quiet.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: Your first Lightning receive triggers channel creation. Phoenix must commit an on-chain transaction to open the channel, which incurs the current Bitcoin mining fee plus a 1,000 sat setup charge.

fees_scenarios.title: Big receive
fees_scenarios.what_happens: Phoenix resizes your channel to accept more sats than current capacity allows.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Consolidate into fewer, larger receives; spend down balance before receiving large amounts.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: When incoming payment exceeds available channel capacity, Phoenix performs a splice-in operation. This on-chain transaction increases your channel size and costs 1% of the received amount plus current mining fees.

fees_faq.q: Does Phoenix charge me every time I receive?
fees_faq.a: Not always. Once your channel exists and has room, small Lightning receives can be free aside from routing.

fees_faq.q: When will Phoenix open or resize a channel?
fees_faq.a: On your first Lightning receive or when more inbound capacity is needed.

fees_faq.q: How do I avoid the 1% splice fee?
fees_faq.a: Consolidate larger receives and avoid on-chain fee spikes.

key_terms.definition: Creates your first Lightning channel so you can receive.
Increases channel capacity to take larger receives.
On-chain fee paid when opening/resizing; varies with network demand.

data_flows: Phoenix connects to ACINQ’s server to run Lightning for you. Today, ACINQ can see who you pay and how much.
You can connect Phoenix to your own Electrum server to reduce what third parties can learn about your activity.
recovery_drill: Your channel states are encrypted and saved with ACINQ so you can restore using your 12-word seed.
The seed lives only on your phone—ACINQ can’t recover it for you if you lose it.
If ACINQ ever disappears, go to Settings → Danger zone → Force close channels; funds return on-chain after ~720 blocks.
Keep Phoenix installed until the forced-closed coins show in the Final wallet view, then sweep them.
country_caveats: Availability and funding options vary by country—check your app store or on-ramp.
Install only from the official publisher in your app store; verify the developer name.

data_flows: Phoenix connects to ACINQ's Lightning node to route payments. Today, ACINQ can see who you pay and the amount needed to deliver your payment.
On-chain transactions are public by design; reuse of addresses can link activity.
Use your own Electrum server (Settings) to limit what third parties learn about your addresses and balances.
Lightning peers still observe timing/amount metadata needed for routing.
privacy.data_flows_do: Connect your own Electrum server if privacy matters.
privacy.data_flows_dont: Assume Lightning is fully private. Some metadata still leaks via peers.
recovery: Your 12-word seed lives only on your phone. ACINQ can't recover it for you. Channel states are encrypted and synced so they can be restored.
Standard restore: install Phoenix → Restore my wallet → enter seed → keep the phone online while channels resync.
If Phoenix/ACINQ is unavailable: Settings → Danger zone → Force close channels. After ~720 blocks, funds appear in the Final wallet; then sweep on-chain.
privacy.recovery_do: Store your seed offline and test a small restore when convenient.
privacy.recovery_dont: Run Phoenix on two phones at the same time.
region: App-store availability and funding options vary by country—check your local listing and on-ramp.
Install only from the official developer (ACINQ) on Apple App Store or Google Play.
Avoid third-party APKs; they're a common source of malware.

micro_faqs.q: Does Phoenix work with my own node or Electrum?
micro_faqs.a: Yes. Connect your Electrum server to improve privacy; Lightning peers still see routing metadata.

micro_faqs.q: Can ACINQ recover my wallet if I lose the seed?
micro_faqs.a: No. The seed never leaves your device.
Use Force close; funds appear in the Final wallet after confirmations, then sweep.

glossary.def: A server your wallet queries for balances/tx history. Running your own improves privacy.
Shuts a Lightning channel on-chain without cooperation; slower and higher fees.
On-chain funds after channels close; sweep when confirmed.

compat_heading: What this Phoenix wallet can or can't do

compat_tiles.title: Pay with Lightning
compat_tiles.benefit: Invoices Pay links Lightning Address

compat_tiles.title: Pay on-chain
compat_tiles.benefit: Send to Bitcoin addresses

compat_tiles.title: Receive on Lightning
compat_tiles.benefit: Invoices Pay links Auto-opens channels

compat_tiles.title: Receive on-chain
compat_tiles.benefit: Converts to Lightning 3 confirmations

compat_explainers.why: Phoenix natively routes payments over Lightning with low fees (0.4% + 4 sat).
try: Scan or paste any Lightning invoice, QR, or address
Review the amount and routing fee
Confirm and payment settles instantly
compat_explainers.gotcha: For very large payments, adjust the maximum fee cap in Settings → Channel management before sending.

compat_explainers.why: You can send to regular Bitcoin addresses by closing channels or using swap-out.
try: Paste a Bitcoin address in the Send field
Phoenix routes via on-chain (swap-out or channel close)
Confirm and wait for blockchain confirmations
compat_explainers.gotcha: On-chain sends incur mining fees that vary with network congestion. Check mempool.space first.

compat_explainers.why: Phoenix automatically manages channels so you can receive without manual setup.
try: Tap Receive and generate a Lightning invoice
Share the QR or invoice with the payer
Phoenix opens or resizes channels if needed (≈1% + mining fee for large receives)
compat_explainers.gotcha: First receive or large amounts may trigger channel creation/splice-in, costing ~1,000 sat + current mining fee.

compat_explainers.why: You can receive Bitcoin from exchanges and other on-chain wallets; Phoenix converts to Lightning.
try: Tap Receive → Bitcoin address
Share the address with the sender
After 3 confirmations, Phoenix swaps funds into your Lightning channel automatically
compat_explainers.gotcha: Phoenix waits 3 confirmations before swapping on-chain funds to Lightning. Set a swap fee limit in Settings.

migration.title: Restore Phoenix on a new phone
migration.choose: When you get a new device and want to keep using Phoenix.
steps: Install Phoenix on the new phone and verify it's the official app from ACINQ.
Choose Restore my wallet, enter your 12-word seed, and wait for channels to resync.
Remove Phoenix from the old device once the new install works; never run both simultaneously.
migration.tips: Don't run Phoenix on two phones at the same time: channel states will conflict. Keep the new device online during resync; it may take a few minutes.
migration.gotcha: Android transaction history won't migrate; only your balance and channels restore.

migration.title: Another wallet → to Phoenix
migration.choose: When you want to start using Phoenix but have funds in a different Lightning wallet.
steps: Install Phoenix and complete the initial setup to generate your wallet and first channel.
In Phoenix, tap Receive and generate a Lightning invoice for the amount you want to transfer.
In your old wallet, send the Lightning payment to the Phoenix invoice. Start with a small test (~10,000 sats) first.
migration.tips: Always test with a small amount first. Phoenix will automatically open a channel if needed (costs ~1,000 sat + mining fee). Keep both apps open during the transfer.
migration.gotcha: Your old wallet's channel balance can't be transferred directly—you must send payments to Phoenix, which takes a minute or two.

migration.title: Phoenix → to on-chain wallet
migration.choose: When you want to move Bitcoin for long-term storage.
steps: Open Phoenix, go to Settings > Close channels, and confirm cooperative close (cheapest way to exit).
Wait for closing transactions to confirm (1–6 blocks); funds appear in Phoenix's Final wallet view.
Sweep coins to your preferred on-chain wallet once confirmed.
migration.tips: Prefer cooperative close over force close; it's faster and cheaper. Check current fees before closing; wait for low-fee periods to save sats.
migration.gotcha: Forced close can take up to 5 days and costs more. Only use if ACINQ is offline.

migration.title: Phoenix → to another Lightning wallet
migration.choose: When you want to try a different Lightning wallet and move your Phoenix balance.
steps: Install your new wallet and complete its backup process.
Send a small test payment (~10,000 sats) from Phoenix to the new wallet to verify it works.
Close Phoenix channels (Settings > Close channels) and sweep remaining funds once confirmed.
migration.tips: Test first with a small amount (~10,000 sats) to catch issues before moving everything. Verify the new wallet's recovery model matches your security preferences.

name: Pocket

faqs.a: Pocket is a non‑custodial service for recurring buys that sends Bitcoin directly to your own wallet.
Pocket is KYC‑light; verification applies for larger purchases based on EU regulations.
Pocket focuses on the EU, with support varying by country and bank.

WW.text: Bitcoin will automatically be sent to your wallet

EU.text: Bitcoin will automatically be sent to your wallet

kyc_required: Yes, but only for purchases over €1.000
description:
Pocket Bitcoin stands out with its non-custodial model, sending Bitcoin directly to your wallet without holding funds, and a no-account, KYC-light approach for daily buys up to €1,000 | 0.01 BTC | 0.01 BTC, prioritizing privacy. It offers one-off or recurring buys via bank transfer, with a 1.5% fee and no withdrawal fees, supporting select hardware wallets like Trezor and Ledger with message signing.

Pocket's mission is to make Bitcoin ownership frictionless and private, promoting self-custody without complexity and with a vision to expand to a dozen more European countries and enhance wallet integrations.

The mobile app, and the web portal for managing orders and wallet settings, are praised for their simple interface and fast transactions, but some find the fees slightly high.

name: Relai

faqs.a: Relai is a beginner‑friendly Bitcoin app with a built‑in self‑custodial wallet and automatic withdrawals to your address.
Yes. Recurring buys are supported with free tiers up to monthly limits; fees apply above that.
Relai primarily serves Europe and supports SEPA, cards and mobile pay methods.

WW.text: Bitcoin will automatically be sent to your wallet

EU.text: Bitcoin will automatically be sent to your wallet

dca: Yes: but free only on the first €1.200
description:
Relai, founded in 2020 in Zürich, Switzerland, is an app designed for beginners to buy and save Bitcoin easily. It stands out from competitors with its non-custodial wallet, meaning users control their Bitcoin via a 12-word seed phrase. After purchasing Bitcoin, it will be directly sent to your wallet.

Relai offers purchases starting at €50 | 54,205 sats, one free buy up to €100 | 108,409 sats monthly, until you hit €1200. After that you pay a 1% fee for any transaction. For businesses and wealthy individuals Relai offers personal service and expert guidance.

Its app, rated 4.5 stars on iOS, is praised by users for simple onboarding and smooth navigation, though some users report verification delays or high card fees. Relai focuses on privacy and self-custody, with optional KYC for small transactions.

Its vision is to make Bitcoin saving accessible across Europe, with plans to add Lightning Network support for faster payments. Beginners love its straightforward design and security, but it's limited to Europe and lacks advanced savings features.

name: River

faqs.a: River is a U.S. Bitcoin platform with full‑reserve custody, recurring buys and Lightning payments.
Fees are volume‑based with transparent tiers; recurring orders are free to set and manage.

faqs.q: Is River available outside the U.S.?
faqs.a: River primarily serves the U.S.; availability outside the U.S. is limited.

description:
River helps U.S. based customers invest in Bitcoin simply and securely with a focus on long-term saving. Unlike many platforms, River holds all Bitcoin in full-reserve cold storage with multi-signature security and gives users transparency through real-time proof of reserves. This might sound inviting to people who don't want to hold Bitcoin in self-custody but it also means more centralization within Bitcoin.

It supports things like inheritance planning, business accounts, and joint accounts, making it attractive for people who want to treat Bitcoin like serious money. Users can buy Bitcoin instantly, set up automated savings, and send Bitcoin via on-chain or Lightning payments. On top of that, you can earn 3.8% Bitcoin interest on your cash. The app has a clean interface and is designed to be easy to use, earning high ratings on both iOS and Android.

River's mission is to provide a trusted, high-quality experience for people who want to build wealth in Bitcoin without distractions. It aims to give users full control and transparency. While some users note strict ID verification and limited availability outside the U.S., River is praised for its reliability, personal customer service, and focus on security.

name: RoboSats

faqs.a: RoboSats is a privacy‑first, Lightning‑native peer‑to‑peer exchange to buy and sell bitcoin without accounts or KYC, primarily accessed over Tor.
No. RoboSats has no registration or KYC; trades use one‑time robot identities tied to a secret token you control.
Both parties lock small Lightning bonds and the seller locks a Lightning hold‑invoice as escrow. After fiat is confirmed, sats are released.

WW.text: Requires Tor/I2P or compatible Android app
Trade size limited by Lightning liquidity

description:
RoboSats is a privacy‑first, Lightning‑native peer‑to‑peer exchange for buying and selling bitcoin with fiat. It is open‑source, requires no registration or KYC, and runs primarily over Tor (with I2P and an Android app available). Each trade uses a one‑time “robot” identity tied to a secret token you control, and all peer chat is end‑to‑end encrypted with PGP. The flow is simple: make or take an order, both sides lock small Lightning bonds, the seller locks a Lightning hold‑invoice escrow, fiat moves, then sats are released.

What separates RoboSats is how deeply privacy and safety are built into the mechanics rather than bolted on. One‑trade identities reduce linkability across orders, PGP‑sealed chat prevents metadata leakage, and Lightning hold invoices act as both escrow and fidelity bonds to discourage cancellations and fraud. Pricing is transparent and market‑relative, fees are low at 0.2% split between maker and taker, and optional on‑chain payouts are handled via swaps. Clear best‑practice guides help users pick lower‑risk fiat rails and avoid chargeback traps.

The ideal audience is anyone who wants fast, low‑fee, no‑KYC bitcoin for modest amounts and is comfortable using Tor and a compatible Lightning wallet. Trade sizes are tuned to what routes reliably on Lightning today, which suits frequent smaller buys and sells. The UI is straightforward once you learn the token/robot model, and the documentation walks through wallet compatibility, order timing, disputes, and payment‑method hygiene to keep trades quick and clean.

RoboSats’ vision is to keep P2P bitcoin simple, private, and resilient, with a path toward a federated network of coordinators sharing a unified order book to reduce single‑operator risk while preserving the familiar UX.

name: Sparrow

faqs.a: Sparrow is a powerful non‑custodial desktop wallet with advanced coin control and hardware wallet support.

faqs.q: Does Sparrow support my own node?
faqs.a: Yes. Sparrow connects to Bitcoin Core or your own Electrum server, including over Tor.
Yes. Sparrow is open‑source and actively maintained.

node_connect: Yes – Bitcoin Core or Electrum server (Tor supported)
description:
Sparrow Wallet is a desktop Bitcoin wallet designed to give users full control over their bitcoin. It was created by developer Craig Raw and is open-source, privacy-focused, and ideal for both beginners and advanced users. The wallet works on Windows, macOS, and Linux.

What separates Sparrow from other wallets is its balance between simplicity and advanced features. Beginners can start with a basic hot wallet setup and gradually explore more complex features like hardware wallet integration, multisig vaults, and UTXO control—all within the same interface. It gives users direct visibility into how Bitcoin works, showing transaction details, input and output flows, and allowing for precise control over fees and coin selection. This level of transparency helps users understand and manage their funds more deliberately.

User reviews highlight how Sparrow scales with you as you learn. It is refered to as the most powerful and versatile Bitcoin wallet, and users praise its clean layout, customizable setup, and educational value. Despite its many features, the app's interface is considered clear and organized once users get past the initial learning curve.

Sparrow's vision is to offer users complete sovereignty over their bitcoin. It avoids mobile compromises and instead focuses on a desktop experience that can integrate with cold storage, your own node, and advanced privacy tools. For beginners who want to grow into more advanced use cases without switching wallets, Sparrow offers a flexible and educational path to full control.

name: Start9
type_of_platform: Home server as software and / or hardware

faqs.a: Start9 offers StartOS and plug‑and‑play personal servers (Server One/Pure) to self‑host Bitcoin, Lightning and many apps.
StartOS is source‑available; many bundled apps are open‑source.
Use Server One/Pure for turnkey support, or install StartOS on your own x86/Raspberry Pi for DIY control.

support: Community forums and Premium support (Free with device)
description:
Start9 (Start9 Labs) is the creator of the Embassy—a turnkey, self-hosted personal server and Bitcoin stack powered by their open-source StartOS. Their mission is to eliminate reliance on centralized third parties, placing privacy, decentralization, and individual autonomy at the forefront. Unlike other DIY solutions, Start9 aims to "level the playing field," offering plug-and-play hardware kits (like Embassy One and Embassy Pro) or a do-it-yourself image for Raspberry Pi or x86, all fully supported by their first-class community and expert support team.

Start9's target users are privacy-conscious individuals, Bitcoiners, and anyone seeking digital autonomy without sacrificing usability. They prioritize delivering polished self-sovereign computing with high-quality hardware, intuitive interfaces, and expert support (via Matrix) to onboard less technical users while remaining fully transparent and open-source. Users appreciate its robust foundation, modular update system (allowing single-service patching), backup ease, and strong headless health checking—compared to alternatives like Umbrel.

Looking forward, Start9 envisions a world where personal servers become the backbone of a sovereign internet and smart homes, enabling blockchain-native apps, decentralized messaging, password managers, file storage, and more. Their open hardware and software philosophy ensures that even if the company disappears, the ecosystem lives on—fully community-driven and censorship-resistant.

name: Strike

faqs.a: No. Strike is custodial, but you can withdraw on‑chain or via Lightning for free to self‑custody.
Support focuses on North America, Europe, South America and Australia; some features like Bill Pay are U.S. only.
Trading fees follow a tiered volume schedule; recurring orders are free after setup.

description:
Strike's goal is to make worldwide payments in Bitcoin as easy as possible, it offers free on‑chain and Lightning withdrawals, making it flexible and cost‑effective to hold your Bitcoin in self-custody. Its recurring buy feature at no fee costs after the initial setup, makes DCA (dollar‑cost averaging) simple and efficient. Strike also functions as a Lightning wallet, enabling quick micropayments with features like unique payment links and cash-to-Bitcoin transfers, and offers responsive customer support praised by users.

Strike's vision goes beyond being merely another payment app. It aims to democratize financial access, reduce dependency on traditional banks, and promote financial sovereignty by empowering individuals to manage their money independently. Their user-friendly app interface, available on both iOS and Android, highlights simplicity and accessibility with a minimalistic design.

In the US, Strike now offers a powerful Bill Pay feature aiming to reduce reliance on fiat currency and combat inflation by leveraging Bitcoin's appreciating value, with automated tax reporting to simplify the process.

Another Strike feature is the Bitcoin‑backed loan that lets users pledge Bitcoin as collateral and borrow USD with no origination or early repayment fees. Loans can be repaid anytime without penalties.

name: Swan

faqs.a: Swan is a Bitcoin savings platform with recurring buys, education and IRA products for U.S. users.
Yes. Swan encourages self‑custody and supports automatic withdrawals to your address.
Swan primarily serves the U.S.; availability elsewhere is limited.

dca: Yes: but with fees after the first $10.000
description:
Swan Bitcoin, launched by Cory Klippsten and based in California, is a platform focused on making it easy for beginners to buy and save Bitcoin.

What makes Swan distinct is its focus on self-custody support and education. It automatically withdraws BTC weekly to your own address and provides guides for self-custody, while also offering Swan Guard with fraud protection and identity verification tools. Swan prioritizes teaching users about Bitcoin's value for financial freedom. Swan also targets long-term savers by offering IRA products making Bitcoin tax-advantaged retirement savings easier.

Swan offers zero-fee purchases on the first $10,000, a low 0.99% fee for recurring buys, and free withdrawals to personal wallets, encouraging self-custody. Its app is praised for its clean design and simple setup. However, some users report slow customer support and issues with account restrictions.

Its vision is to onboard 10 million Bitcoin users by promoting Bitcoin as better money for a decentralized future.

name: Umbrel
type_of_platform: Home server as software and / or hardware

faqs.a: Umbrel is a user‑friendly home server OS to self‑host Bitcoin/Lightning nodes and 100+ apps via a one‑click App Store.
Umbrel is source‑available rather than fully open‑source; many apps are open‑source.
Yes. Umbrel supports secure remote access via Tor and Tailscale VPN.

WW.text: Remote access via Tor or Tailscale VPN

description:
Umbrel is a user-friendly, plug‑and‑play home server OS primarily designed to run Bitcoin and Lightning nodes. It supports the official Umbrel Home hardware and installation on Raspberry Pi or x86 machines. What sets it apart is its polished, macOS‑style interface with a one‑click App Store for installing things like Bitcoin Core, LND, Electrum Rust Server, mempool explorer, and various self‑hosted apps like Nextcloud, Plex, Pi‑Hole, Home Assistant, and AI models. The setup process is straightforward—just plug in, set a password, install apps, and sync—which makes it accessible for non‑technical users.

What truly distinguishes Umbrel is its elegant design and focus on broad self‑hosting beyond just Bitcoin. The dashboard offers real‑time system stats, customizable widgets, seamless updates, and integrations for VPN access via Tailscale or TOR. The App Store's curated ecosystem of over 100 vetted, containerized apps makes complex tasks like running blockchain explorers or home automation easy—without requiring command‑line work. This polished UX lowers the bar for users who want to self‑host smartly.

In terms of community and support, Umbrel has an active user base and support channels via chat and forums. However, discussions also mention that Umbrel uses unencrypted HTTP by default and lacks HTTPS, which could pose risks on exposed LANs. More privacy‑focused alternatives like Citadel and StartOS offer full HTTPS and fully open‑source licensing.

Umbrel is aimed at users seeking a seamless, beautiful entry point into self‑sovereign Bitcoin and home‑server use. Its vision is to expand the personal server experience by enabling anyone to host their own apps, AI, media, and nodes with minimal friction. But it trades off some transparency and technical control—its source‑available license, lack of HTTPS out of the box, and centralized update model may concern advanced or privacy‑focused users. In sum, Umbrel offers a delightful, low‑barrier way to participate in Bitcoin sovereignty and self‑hosting, though some might prefer more open or secure setups if they prioritize full technical autonomy.

name: Unchained

faqs.a: Unchained provides collaborative custody (2‑of‑3 multisig) with concierge onboarding and inheritance support.
Yes. As a regulated U.S. service, identity verification is required.
Individuals and businesses who want recovery‑friendly self‑custody with professional assistance when needed.

recovery_method: Unchained can co-sign if a key is lost
description:
Unchained is a Bitcoin financial services company focused on helping individuals and businesses secure their Bitcoin through collaborative custody. Their main product is a multisig vault that uses a 2-of-3 key setup, where the user holds two keys and Unchained holds the third. This setup allows users to maintain full control over their Bitcoin while enabling Unchained to assist in recovery if needed, without ever having unilateral access to the funds.

What makes Unchained unique is its emphasis on combining technical security with user support. Unlike standard hardware wallet setups that rely on a single point of failure, Unchained's model is resistant to user error and device loss. Even if you lose 75% of your devices or backups, you can still recover your funds with Unchained's help. Their system also facilitates inheritance by allowing next of kin to recover funds with proper documentation, making it especially appealing for those thinking about long-term wealth protection.

Unchained users appreciate the guided onboarding, live support, and optional concierge services that simplify the complex process of setting up multisig. The platform integrates with popular hardware wallets, and allows users to manage their funds through Unchained's dashboard or export and interact with their vault using open-source tools. The ability to spend from your vault without relying on the Unchained website gives users additional peace of mind.

The company's long-term vision is to build a robust financial ecosystem based on Bitcoin-native tools, including multisig-secured lending, inheritance planning, and business services. While the setup requires ID verification and Unchained knows the vault balances, many users view this trade-off as acceptable in exchange for improved recovery options and strong operational security.

Unchained is best suited for those seeking to remove single points of failure in their Bitcoin custody, want professional assistance when needed, and value redundancy and inheritance planning—all while retaining full self-custody.

name: Wasabi

faqs.a: Wasabi is an open‑source, non‑custodial desktop wallet focused on privacy with built‑in CoinJoin.
Yes. Wasabi routes traffic over Tor and uses compact filters to protect your IP and balance privacy.
Wasabi offers a clear interface, but privacy features like CoinJoin may require learning for new users.

profile: Balint Harmat, Adam Ficsor & Gergely Hajdu
description:
Wasabi Wallet is a privacy-focused, open-source, non‑custodial Bitcoin desktop wallet launched by zkSNACKs. It routes all traffic through Tor and uses compact blockchain filters, keeping your IP and balance private. Its standout feature is built-in CoinJoin, a process that mixes your Bitcoin with others' to make it harder for anyone to trace your transactions, enhancing privacy without relying on third parties.

The user interface is straightforward but functional, with a dashboard showing your balance, privacy progress, and transaction history, though it may feel technical for complete beginners. Setup involves writing down a 12-word seed phrase and an optional passphrase, which adds security but requires careful storage.

What sets Wasabi apart is its strong focus on privacy through CoinJoin, which is seamlessly integrated and doesn't require manual setup, making it accessible for newcomers. It also allows advanced users to connect to custom coordinators via platforms like Nostr, ensuring privacy even if default services are unavailable.

Wasabi is for people who want to own their Bitcoin without having to trust big companies. It hides your transactions by mixing them with others, runs silently in the background over Tor, and gives you full control—all on your own computer. Its goal is to make privacy easy and powerful, while building toward a future where you don't rely on any single server.
